metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Qinghai Lake integrated observatory network (an observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of Alpine meadow and grassland ecosystem Superstation, 2019)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Qinghai Lake integrated observatory network obtained from an observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of the Alpine meadow and grassland ecosystem Superstation from September 3 in 2018 to December 31 in 2019. The site (98°35′41.62″E, 37°42′11.47″N) was located in the alpine meadow and alpine grassland ecosystem, near the SuGe Road in Tianjun County, Qinghai Province. The elevation is 3718m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (HMP155; 3, 5, 10, 15, 20, 30, and 40 m, towards north), wind speed and direction profile (windsonic; 3, 5, 10, 15, 20, 30, and 40 m, towards north), air pressure (PTB110; 3 m), rain gauge (TE525M; 10m of the platform in west by north of tower), four-component radiometer (CNR4; 6m, towards south), two infrared temperature sensors (SI-111; 6 m, towards south, vertically downward), photosynthetically active radiation (PQS1; 6 m, towards south, each with one vertically downward and one vertically upward, soil heat flux (HFP01; 3 duplicates below the vegetation; -0.06 m), soil temperature profile (109; -0.05、-0.10、-0.20、-0.40、-0.80、-1.20、-2.00、-3.00 and -4.00m), soil moisture profile (CS616; -0.05、-0.10、-0.20、-0.40、-0.80、-1.20、-2.00、-3.00 and -4.00m).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_3 m, Ta_5 m, Ta_10 m, Ta_15 m, Ta_20 m, Ta_30 m, and Ta_40 m; RH_3 m, RH_5 m, RH_10 m, RH_15 m, RH_20 m, RH_30 m, and RH_40 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_3 m, Ws_5 m, Ws_10 m, Ws_15 m, Ws_20 m, Ws_30 m, and Ws_40 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_3 m, WD_5 m, WD_10 m, WD_15 m, WD_20 m, WD_30m, and WD_40 m) (°), precipitation (rain) (mm), air pressure (press) (hpa), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_D_up and PAR_D_down) (μmol/ (s m-2)), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_5cm、Ts_10cm、Ts_20cm、Ts_40cm、Ts_80cm、Ts_120cm、Ts_200cm、Ts_300cm、Ts_400cm) (℃), soil moisture (Ms_5cm、Ms_10cm、Ms_20cm、Ms_40cm、Ms_80cm、Ms_120cm、Ms_200cm、Ms_300cm、Ms_400cm) (%, volumetric water content).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2018/8/31 10:30. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

Definition.Question: What is a two-source energy balance (TSEB) model in the context of evapotranspiration estimation?
Definition.Answer: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model is a method to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation. It accounts for both 'above canopy' and 'under soil' cases in energy partition, addressing the heterogeneous nature of mixed soil and vegetation surfaces, and improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation and temperatures.

Definition.Question: What are the key components of a meteorological observation system in a high-altitude grassland-superstation?
Definition.Answer: A high-altitude grassland-superstation meteorological observation system includes sensors for wind speed and direction at multiple heights, air temperature and humidity sensors, a barometer, a tipping bucket rain gauge, a four-component radiometer, infrared thermometers for surface temperature, soil heat flux plates, soil moisture and temperature probes at various depths, and a photosynthetically active radiation sensor.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for meteorological parameters in the Qilian Mountain Comprehensive Observation Network compare to those used in the Daman superstation?
Comparison.Answer: The Qilian Mountain Comprehensive Observation Network collects meteorological parameters at multiple heights (3m to 40m) and includes a wide range of sensors for wind speed, temperature, humidity, and radiation, among others, focusing on different soil depths as well. In contrast, the Daman superstation measures parameters at fewer heights, such as 5m and 12m, and emphasizes the use of a high-resolution thermal camera for soil and canopy temperature measurements. Both methods aim to capture detailed meteorological data but employ different approaches and technologies based on their specific research objectives.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of soil and canopy component temperatures improve the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimations in heterogeneous landscapes?
Interpretation.Answer: By using ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures, evapotranspiration estimations can be better validated with observed ratios using stable isotopes and eddy covariance measurements. This integration allows for more accurate partitioning of latent heat fluxes into soil and vegetation components, which is crucial in heterogeneous landscapes with mixed vegetation and soil surfaces.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential challenges in using thermal infrared cameras for data collection in agricultural areas, and how can these challenges be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include image classification errors affecting component temperature accuracy, particularly in areas with varying vegetation abundance. These can lead to misclassification of soil and vegetation pixels, resulting in inaccurate temperature readings. Addressing these challenges might involve refining image classification techniques and considering atmospheric factors affecting radiation measurements.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can data quality control measures enhance the reliability of meteorological datasets collected from high-altitude observation stations?
Interpretation.Answer: Data quality control measures, such as ensuring complete data records, removing duplicate or physically implausible data points, and flagging questionable data, help enhance the reliability of datasets. These measures ensure that the data accurately represent environmental conditions, which is essential for high-altitude stations where conditions can be extreme and variable.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in accurately estimating evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes using data collection methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Accurately estimating surface fluxes in heterogeneous landscapes is challenging due to the complexity of energy exchange between soil and vegetation, variations in surface temperatures, and resistance to energy exchange. Errors in determining component temperatures from radiometric measurements can affect model performance, particularly in advective environments.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the limitation in applying existing evapotranspiration models to operational satellite and ground-based data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Existing evapotranspiration models are limited in their application to operational satellite and ground-based data due to the complexity of the models, which require parameters and observations that are not readily available. The models also tend to have multiple resistances and complex energy partition assumptions that are difficult to calculate accurately.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using multi-layer meteorological sensors for data accuracy in measuring atmospheric conditions over high-altitude grasslands?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using multi-layer meteorological sensors can significantly enhance data accuracy by capturing atmospheric conditions at various altitudes, which helps in understanding the vertical gradient of weather elements such as wind speed, temperature, and humidity. This comprehensive data collection can improve model estimations for evapotranspiration and other surface processes, especially in complex terrains like high-altitude grasslands.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the inclusion of soil temperature and moisture sensors at varying depths impact the understanding of soil-vegetation-atmosphere interactions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Incorporating soil temperature and moisture sensors at varying depths allows for detailed insights into soil-vegetation-atmosphere interactions. This can help in accurately modeling soil heat flux and moisture dynamics, which are crucial for estimating evapotranspiration and improving land surface models. It provides a better understanding of how soil conditions affect vegetation growth and surface energy balance.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the effects of integrating high-resolution thermal imaging with ground-based measurements on the accuracy of evapotranspiration models?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating high-resolution thermal imaging with ground-based measurements can significantly enhance the accuracy of evapotranspiration models by providing precise soil and canopy component temperatures. This allows for more accurate partitioning of sensible and latent heat fluxes, improving the model's reliability in estimating evaporation and transpiration rates, especially in heterogeneous landscapes like the ones observed in the experimental area.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to use high-resolution thermal imagery for estimating evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: High-resolution thermal imagery allows for precise measurement of soil and canopy component temperatures, which are critical for accurately estimating evaporation, transpiration, and overall evapotranspiration in landscapes with mixed soil and vegetation, addressing the limitations of traditional single-source models.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to ensure the quality and accuracy of meteorological data collected in high-altitude environments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data processing and quality control involve ensuring there are 144 data points collected every day, marking missing data with -6999, removing duplicate records, deleting data that are physically implausible or beyond the instrument's range, and flagging questionable data in red. Date and time are formatted consistently, with both being in the same column.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can ground-based measurements be effectively integrated with remote sensing data to improve the estimation of evapotranspiration components in mixed landscape environments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Ground-based measurements such as soil and canopy component temperatures can be used to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET), with validation using stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes and eddy covariance (EC) system measurements. The TSEB model utilizes these ground measurements, and the component temperatures are calculated using thermal camera images, converting them to radiation temperatures considering incoming long-wave radiation and emissivities.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological approaches are employed to separate soil and vegetation component temperatures from composite radiometric temperature measurements in agricultural regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The approach involves using thermal infrared camera images classified into soil and canopy pixels with the maximum-likelihood method. Soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures are extracted from these thermal images. The thermal infrared temperatures are then converted to radiation temperatures, validated against surface radiometric temperatures calculated from incoming long-wave radiation observed by a four-component radiometer.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary for the effective deployment of a multi-layered meteorological observation system in high-altitude mixed terrains?
Enablement.Answer: The effective deployment of a multi-layered meteorological observation system in high-altitude mixed terrains requires precise positioning of sensors at various heights and orientations, such as wind speed/direction sensors at 3m to 40m facing north, and careful installation of other instruments like infrared thermometers and soil sensors at specified depths and orientations to ensure accurate data collection across different environmental conditions.

Enablement.Question: How can the integration of ground-based measurement systems with advanced imaging technologies enhance the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimates in heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of ground-based measurement systems with advanced imaging technologies, such as using thermal cameras and high-resolution thermal images, enables the accurate separation of soil and canopy component temperatures. This separation improves the estimation of evapotranspiration, evaporation, and transpiration rates by providing precise inputs for models like the TSEB, which can be validated against stable isotope techniques and eddy covariance measurements.

Enablement.Question: What technological and methodological advancements enable the accurate measurement of soil and canopy component temperatures in complex agricultural settings?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements such as the use of high-precision thermal infrared cameras and the maximum-likelihood classification method for separating soil and canopy pixels from thermal images facilitate the accurate measurement of soil and canopy component temperatures. These methodologies allow for the effective modeling and validation of energy fluxes in complex agricultural settings, leading to reliable estimates of latent heat flux and evapotranspiration components.

Expectation.Question: Why might the data collection method for soil and canopy component temperatures require further refinement in arid regions?
Expectation.Answer: The current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions, leading to difficulties in accurately measuring evaporation and transpiration on the ground. Errors primarily arise from image classification errors, particularly due to variations in vegetation abundance, affecting the estimation of canopy temperature.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected benefits of using stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes in validating evapotranspiration measurements in combination with eddy covariance systems?
Expectation.Answer: Using stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes in combination with eddy covariance systems is expected to provide better validation of estimated evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration. This combination helps in accurately partitioning the fluxes between soil and canopy, thus contributing to more reliable evapotranspiration estimates.

Judgmental.Question: What are your thoughts on the effectiveness of using ground-based measurement data in partitioning evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration in the context of complex landscape conditions?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of ground-based measurement data, such as that from the eddy covariance system and thermal infrared cameras, provides a robust method for partitioning evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration. This approach can be effective, especially when coupled with models like the TSEB, which have been shown to provide reliable estimates even in strongly advective conditions. However, challenges such as image classification errors and atmospheric radiation influences need careful consideration.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how can datasets of meteorological parameters from different layers above the ground improve the understanding of surface energy balance in high-altitude regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Datasets of meteorological parameters from multiple layers above the ground can significantly enhance the understanding of surface energy balance in high-altitude regions. By providing detailed profiles of wind speed, temperature, humidity, and radiation at various heights, these datasets allow for a more comprehensive analysis of atmospheric conditions, which is crucial for models that estimate energy exchanges between the surface and the atmosphere. This layered approach can lead to better insights into the interactions between soil, vegetation, and atmospheric components.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the data collection techniques utilized for recording meteorological parameters in high-altitude regions and identify any potential challenges faced during this process.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection techniques involve installing sensors at various heights (3m to 40m) to measure wind speed, wind direction, air temperature, and relative humidity. Additional instruments like barometers, rain gauges, and radiometers are utilized for recording pressure, precipitation, and radiation. Challenges include ensuring data completeness, eliminating duplicate records, and filtering out data that exceed physical or instrumental limits.

Request/Directive.Question: Please evaluate the methodologies employed for processing and quality control of meteorological data collected from high-altitude mixed grassland and alpine meadow environments.
Request/Directive.Answer: The methodologies include ensuring a consistent data recording frequency (144 records per day, every 10 minutes), marking missing data with a specific code (-6999), removing duplicate records, and excluding data beyond physical or instrumental ranges. Data with potential issues are highlighted for further review, ensuring uniform date and time formatting in a single column.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that can be utilized to validate the estimation of evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes using models such as the two-source energy balance model.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets include those that provide ground-based measurements of soil and canopy component temperatures, such as those obtained from high-resolution thermal cameras and eddy covariance systems. These datasets can be validated with stable isotope techniques and compared with model outputs, offering insights into the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimations in diverse vegetation and climatic conditions.
